title: 4. Method
text: Let us set notations first. Suppose exists partition region \({\rm D} \{\cal R}^2\) (e.g., city). partition denoted \(A_i\), \(= 1, \ldots, n\). Moreover, exists another parition city, denoted \(B_j\), \(j = 1, \ldots, m\). partitions can seen two different administrative divisions within city. common different government agencies release data different divisions city, country, state.

title: 4. Method
text: Assume observe random variable \(Y(\cdot)\) region \(A_i\) interested predict/estimate variable regions \(B_j\). Now suppose random variable \(Y(\cdot)\) varies continuously \({\rm D}\) defined follows \[ Y(\mathbf{s}) = \mu + S(\mathbf{s}) + \varepsilon(\mathbf{s}), \, \mathbf{s} \{\rm D} \subset {\cal R}^2. \] \[ S(\cdot) \sim {\rm GP}(0, \sigma^2 \rho(\cdot; \, \phi, \kappa)) \; \text{ } \; \varepsilon(\cdot) \overset{{\rm ..d.}}{\sim} {\rm N}(0, \sigma^2 \rho(\cdot; \, \phi, \kappa)), \] \(S\) \(\varepsilon\) independent . now, let’s make unrealistic assumption parameters known. , assumption observed data follows \[\begin{align*} Y(A_i) & = \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert} \int_{A_i} Y(\mathbf{s}) \, {\rm d} \mathbf{s} \\ & = \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert} \int_{A_i} [\mu + S(\mathbf{s}) + \varepsilon(\mathbf{s})] \, {\rm d} \mathbf{s} \\ & = \mu + \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert} \int_{A_i} S(\mathbf{s}) {\rm d} \mathbf{s} + \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert} \int_{A_i} \varepsilon(\mathbf{s}) {\rm d} \mathbf{s}, \end{align*}\] \(\lvert \cdot \rvert\) returns area polygon. Furthermore, can shown (using Fubini’s Theorem algebraic manipulation) \[ {\rm Cov}(Y(A_i), Y(A_j)) = \frac{\sigma^2}{\lvert A_i \rvert \lvert A_j \rvert} \int_{A_i \times A_j} \rho( \lVert \mathbf{s} - \mathbf{s}' \rVert; \, \phi, \kappa ) \, {\rm d} \mathbf{s} \, {\rm d} \mathbf{s}' + \mathbf{}(= j) \frac{\tau}{\lvert A_i \rvert}, \] \(\rho(\cdot ; \, \phi, \kappa)\) positive definite correlation function. Now, let \({\rm R}_{\kappa}(\phi)\) correlation matrix \[ {\rm R}_{\kappa}(\phi)_{ij} = \frac{1}{\lvert A_i \rvert \lvert A_j \rvert} \int_{A_i \times A_j} \rho( \lVert \mathbf{s} - \mathbf{s}' \rVert; \, \phi, \kappa ) \, {\rm d} \mathbf{s} \, {\rm d} \mathbf{s}', \] thus, \[ Y(A_1, \cdots, A_n) \sim {\rm N}( \mu \mathbf{1}_n, \sigma^2 {\rm R}_{\kappa}(\phi) + \tau {\rm diag}(\lvert A_1 \rvert^{-1}, \ldots, \lvert A_1 \rvert^{-1})). \] , assume \((Y^{\top}(A_1, \cdots, A_n), Y^{\top}(B_1, \cdots, A_m)^{\top})\) jointly normal, use can conditional mean \(Y^{\top}(B_1, \cdots, A_m)^{\top}\) given \(Y^{\top}(A_1, \cdots, A_n)\) estimate observed random variable partition \(B_1, \ldots, B_m\). Now, suppose parameters \(\boldsymbol{\theta} = (\mu, \sigma^2, \phi, \tau)\) unknown. Likelihood \(Y(A_1, \ldots, A_n)\) can still computed. particular, use parametrization \(\nu = \tau / \sigma^2\), closed form Maximum Likelihood estimators \(\mu\) \(\sigma^2\). Thus, can optimize profile likelihood \(\phi\) \(\nu\) numerically. , resort conditional Normal properties compute predictions new different set regions.

title: 4. Method
text: Areal interpolation nonparametric approach interpolates \(Y(A_i)\)’s construct \(Y(B_j)\)’s. Define \(m \times n\) matrix \(\mathbf{W} = \{ w_{ij} \}\), \(w_{ij}\) weight associated polygon \(A_i\) constructing \(Y(B_j)\). weights \(w_{ij} = \lvert A_i \cap B_j \rvert / \lvert B_j \rvert\) (Goodchild Lam 1980; Gotway Young 2002). interpolation \(\hat Y(B_1, \ldots, B_m)\) constructed \[\begin{equation}   \label{eq:np-est}   \hat{Y}(B_1, \ldots, B_m) = \mathbf{W}   Y(A_1, \ldots, A_n). \end{equation}\] expectation variance predictor , respectively, \[   {\rm E}[\hat{Y}(B_1, \ldots, B_m)] = \mathbf{W}   {\rm E}[Y(A_1, \ldots, A_n)] \] \[\begin{equation}   \label{eq:np-matcov}   \textrm{Var}[\hat{Y}(B_1, \ldots, B_m)] = \mathbf{W}   \textrm{Var}[Y(A_1, \ldots, A_n)] \mathbf{W}^{\top}. \end{equation}\] practice, covariance matrix \(\textrm{Var}[Y(A_1, \ldots, A_n)]\) unknown , consequently needs estimated. variance predictor \(\text{Var}[\hat Y(B_i)]\) needed uncertainty measure. relies variances \(Y(A_j)\)’s covariances: \[\begin{align}   \label{eq:np-single-var}   \textrm{Var}[\hat{Y}(B_i)]   = \sum_{= 1}^n w^2_{ij} \textrm{Var} \left [ Y(A_i) \right ] + 2 \sum_{l   \neq } w_{ij} w_{il} \textrm{Cov} \left[ Y(A_i), Y(A_l) \right]. \end{align}\] variances often observed survey data, covariances . practical purpose, propose approximation \(\textrm{Cov}[ Y(A_i), Y(A_l)]\) based Moran’s , global spatial autocorrelation. Specifically, let \(\rho_I\) Moran’s calculated weight matrix constructed first-degree neighbors. , \(\rho_I\) average pairwise correlation neighboring pairs. regions \(A_i\) \(A_l\), neighbors , approximation \[\begin{align}   \label{eq:cova}   \textrm{Cov} \left[ Y(A_i), Y(A_l) \right]   = \rho_I \sqrt{\text{Var}[Y(A_i)]  \text{Var}[Y(A_l)]}. \end{align}\] covariance non-neighboring \(A_i\) \(A_l\) discarded. final uncertainty approximation \(\textrm{Var}[\hat{Y}(B_i)]\) underestimate. Alternatively, can derive, least, upper bound variance estimates using simple application Cauchy–Schwartz inequality, case, \(\rho_I\) replaced ~1.

title: Areal Interpolation — AI
code: data(nyc_surv) data(nyc_comd)  ## creating variables that store the variance for each area ## this is done to exemplify the functionality of the package nyc_surv <- transform(nyc_surv,                       my_var = moe / qnorm(p = .975)) nyc_surv <- transform(nyc_surv, my_var = my_var * my_var)  if (FALSE) { ## areal interpolation estimate_comd <-    ai(source = nyc_surv, target = nyc_comd,       vars = "estimate")  ## areal interpolation with uncertainty estimation estimate_comd <-    ai_var(source = nyc_surv, target = nyc_comd,           vars = "estimate", vars_var = "my_var",           var_method = "MI") }

Note , dimension theta_st depends 2 factors. 1) number variables analyzed, 2) input spm object. ... additionnal parameters, either passed optim. model character scalar indicating family covariance function used. options c("matern",     "pexp", "gaussian", "spherical", "gw"). theta_st numeric (named) vector containing initial parameters. nu numeric value indicating either \(\nu\) paramater Matern covariance function (controlling process differentiability), "pexp" Powered Exponential family. model chosen user Matern nu informed, automatically set .5. hand, user choses Powered Exponential family inform nu, set 1. cases, covariance function becomes covalled exponential covariance function. tr tapper range kappa \(\kappa \\{0, \ldots, 3 \}\) parameter GW cov function. mu2 smoothness parameter \(\mu\) GW function. apply_exp logical scalar indicating wheter parameters assume negative values exponentiate . opt_method character scalar indicating optimization algorithm used. details, see optim. control_opt named list containing control arguments optimization algorithm used. details, see optim. comp_hess boolean indicating whether Hessian matrix computed. phi_min numeric scalar representing minimum \(phi\) value look . phi_max numeric scalar representing maximum \(phi\) value look . nphi numeric scalar indicating number values compute grid-search \(phi\).

title: Fitting an underlying continuous process to areal data — fit_spm
text: function uses optim function optimization algorithms find Maximum Likelihood estimators, standard errors, model adapted . function allows user input control parameters optim function argument control_opt, named list. Additionally, one can input lower upper boundaries optimization problem, well preferred optimization algorithm (long available optim). preferred algorithm selected argument opt_method. addition control optimization, user can select covariance function among following: Matern, Exponential, Powered Exponential, Gaussian, Spherical. parameter apply_exp logical scalar , set TRUE, \(\exp\) function applied nonnegative parameters, allowing optimization algorithm search parameters real numbers.
code: The model assumes \deqn{Y(\mathbf{s}) = \mu + S(\mathbf{s})} at the point level.  Where \eqn{S ~ GP(0, \sigma^2 C(\lVert \mathbf{s} -     \mathbf{s}_2 \rVert; \theta))}.  Further, the observed data is supposed to be \eqn{Y(B) = \lvert B \rvert^{-1} \int_{B} Y(\mathbf{s}) \,     \textrm{d} \mathbf{s}}.

title: Fitting an underlying continuous process to areal data — fit_spm
code: data(liv_lsoa) ## loading the LSOA data  msoa_spm <- sf_to_spm(sf_obj = liv_msoa, n_pts = 500,                       type = "regular", by_polygon = FALSE,                       poly_ids = "msoa11cd",                       var_ids = "leb_est") ## fitting model theta_st_msoa <- c("phi" = 1) # initial value for the range parameter  fit_msoa <-    fit_spm(x = msoa_spm,            theta_st = theta_st_msoa,            model = "matern",            nu = .5,            apply_exp  = TRUE,            opt_method = "L-BFGS-B",            control    = list(maxit = 500))  AIC(fit_msoa) #> [1] 295.1294  summary_spm_fit(fit_msoa, sig = .05) #>  #>  optimization algorithm converged: yes  #>   #>     par   estimate        se               ci #> 1    mu 75.9150132 0.8064157 [74.334; 77.496] #> 2 sigsq 22.5573601 4.0851465 [14.551; 30.564] #> 3   phi  0.8407763 0.2209646   [0.408; 1.274]

Possible values c("matern", "pexp", "gaussian",     "spherical", "cs", "gw", "tapmat"). nu \(\nu\) parameter. necessary model "gaussian" "spherical" tr \(\theta_r\) taper range. kappa \(\kappa \\{0, \ldots, 3 \}\) parameter GW cov function. mu2 smoothness parameter \(\mu\) GW function. apply_exp logical indicater wheter exponential transformation applied variance parameters. facilitates optimization process.
